Co-based catalysts have demonstrated exceptional efficiency catalytic performance for ethylenediamine synthesis from ethylene glycol (EG) amination. However, the electronic effect of Co on the rate-determining step for breaking the CH bond of EG remains unclear, which is critical for EG amination. In the present study, three catalysts Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S were synthesized, and the electronic state of Co species was modulated by changing CeO2 morphologies. Characterization results from TEM, XRD, Raman, H2-TPR, and XPS shown that CeO2 with a higher oxygen vacancy concentration helps stabilize Co2+, which is critical for breaking the CH bond and benefit for EG conversion. While, the lower oxygen vacancy concentration limits NH3 adsorption, which can depress the polymerization enamine intermediate and is benefit for ethylenediamine and ethanolamine synthesis. As a result, the Co/CeO2-R possessing the greatest amount of oxygen vacancy and Co2+ shows the highest EG conversion. While the Co/CeO2-C with fewer oxygen vacancies shows poor NH3 adsorption, depressing the formation of cyclic by-products and improving ethylenediamine and ethanolamine synthesis. A 23.63 % yield for ethylenediamine and ethanolamine was obtained on Co/CeO2-C catalyst. This study systematically examines the impact of CeO2 morphology on Co valence state and EG amination, which is helpful for designing highly effective catalysts for EG amination. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethylene glycol amination Ethylenediamine and ethanolamine Co/CeO2 catalysis Electronic effects of Co Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylenediamine (EDA) is a high-value-added chemical intermediate extensively used in industries such as pharmaceuticals, agriculture, textiles, and resins [1,2]. Traditionally, EDA is produced via the dichloroethane process, which suffers from suboptimal product quality, severe equipment corrosion, and substantial emissions of hazardous waste. Another method, the ethanolamine-based process, faces significant cost constraints due to the high price and limited supply of ethanolamine raw materials, limiting its evolvability [3–6]. Therefore, developing a more sustainable and economically feasible method using abundant and low-cost raw materials are critical for the eco-‍friendly production of EDA. Ethylene glycol, an essential chemical intermediate, is predominantly utilized in the production of polyesters [7]. As coal-based ethylene glycol production has advanced, its capacity has surpassed 2000 t/a, with its price dropping to below 4000 yuan per ton. Utilizing ethylene glycol for EDA production could not only satisfy the growing market demand for EDA but also expand the ethylene glycol industry [8,9]. Currently, limited research has been contributed to the direct amination converting ethylene glycol into produce EDA, with most studies focusing on the amination of ethanolamine intermediates. Two technologies reductive amination and condensation amination have been applied in ethanolamine amination. Compared with condensation amination, reductive amination is a promising and environmentally friendly technology that lies in the higher selectivity for primary amines, lower byproduct selectivity, a simplified process, and lower energy consumption. Two primary categories of catalysts have been devised for the reductive amination of alcohols: noble metal catalysts, such as Ru ‍‍ [10–12] and Ir [13–15], and non-noble metal catalysts, including Co [16–20], Cu [21–24], and Ni [25–29]. In contrast to noble metal catalysts, non-noble metal catalysts are low-cost and highly effective, which makes them more attractive for large-scale industrial applications [30,31]. Among non-noble metal catalysts, Co-based systems have shown superior catalytic performance compared to Ni-based catalysts[32,33]. Sewell et al. [34] reported that the Co/SiO2 catalysts outperformed Ni/SiO2 catalysts in the reductive amination of ethanol when subjected to analogous reaction conditions. Additionally, Zhi Yong Xie et al. [35] demonstrated that the activation energies for OH and CH bond dissociation in ethylene glycol were lower on Co than on Ni, leading to higher EG conversion and greater primary amine yields on Co-based catalysts. Despite these promising results, the amination performance of Co-based catalysts remains far away for industrial applications. So further investigation on the factors influencing their activity is critical for optimizing Co-based catalysts. The generally accepted reaction pathway for ethylene glycol Amination involves the dehydrogenation of ethylene glycol to produce aldehydes, which are then reacted with ammonia to generate imines, which are then hydrogenated to produce ethanolamine. This sequence of dehydrogenation, ammoniation, and hydrogenation is repeated to form EDA [36,37] (see Fig. 1 ). The rate-limiting step in this process is the break of the CH bond of ethylene glycol, requiring a catalyst with strong CH bond activation capabilities [35]. The ability to break the CH bond is closely tied to the charge distribution of the metal in catalysts. Researchers have sought to enhance amination activity by adjusting the valence state of cobalt (Co) and have found that Co0 improves amination reaction performance [38]. However, the lack of systematic studies on how the valence state of Co influences catalytic performance limits further advancements in optimizing Co-based catalysts for amination reactions. The catalyst support plays a critical role in influencing both the valence state and charge distribution of Co in Co-based systems. Cerium oxide (CeO2), a redox-active support, possesses a unique electronic configuration where Ce4+ ions can readily convert to stable Ce3+, releasing active oxygen species to maintain charge balance. These oxygen vacancies can be occupied by oxygen-containing molecules like O2 and H2O, allowing CeO2 to act as an active oxygen carrier. This abundance of oxygen vacancies can facilitate the regulation of the valence state of Co [39]. Tong et al. [40] synthesized a Pt-Co-CeO2 catalyst applying in amination of alcohols and discovered that the unique oxygen vacancy of the CeO2 support can capture oxygen molecules and facilitate electron transfer to Pt and Co. This electron transfer leads Pt+ → Pt0and Co3+ → Co2+, and the Co2+ and Pt0 can enhance the rate-determining step of alcohol dehydrogenation, while by preventing the over-hydrogenation of imine intermediates. Additionally, CeO2 with different morphologies, employs different numbers of oxygen vacancies, which greatly influences the valence and charge distribution of the supported metals. Yan Liu [41] et al. found that in Fischer-Tropsch reactions, the creation of oxygen vacancies on Co/CeO2 can be controlled by modifying the morphology of CeO2, the Co on CeO2-R can gain electrons from oxygen vacancies and show a lower valence state, which can facilitate the performance of CO dissociation in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Furthermore, for EG amination, the catalytic performance is also significantly affected by the absorption capability of NH3 of the catalyst, which can be adjusted by support acidity [42]. In light of the above analysis, controlling the morphology of CeO2 offers a method to adjust surface oxygen vacancies, which in turn can regulate the valence state of Co and its catalytic efficacy in the amination of ethylene glycol. However, no prior studies have specifically investigated this approach. In the present study, CeO2 with different morphologies (R, C, and S) was synthesized as support for Co-based catalysts via a hydrothermal method. A comprehensive characterization including XRD, TEM, SEM, H2-TPD, NH3-TPD, Raman, and XPS techniques was carried out to explore the effects of CeO2 morphology on the distribution of oxygen vacancies and Co valence state, as well as the catalytic activity for ethylene glycol amination to ethylenediamine. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials and reagents Cerium nitrate (Cerium nitrate hexahydrate, Ce (NO3)3·6H2O, 99.5 % metals basis, 10294-41-4); Cobaltous nitrate (Cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate, Co (NO3)2·6H2O, 99.99 % metals basis, 10026-22-9); Sodium hydroxide (Sodium hydroxide, NaOH, 1310-73-2); Anhydrous ethanol (Ethanol, C2H5OH, ≥99.5 %, 64-17-5); Ethylene glycol (Ethylene glycol, C2H6O2, ≥99.5 %, 107-21-1); Propanol (Propanol, C3H8O, ≥99.9 %, 71-23-8); Ammonia solution (Ammonia solution, NH3, ≥99.5 %, 7664-41-7) 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of CeO2 Utilizing methods previously described [43,44], nanorods of CeO2 (CeO2-R), nanocube of CeO2 (CeO2-‍C), and nanosheet of CeO2 (CeO2-S) were synthesized via hydrothermal methods. In the case of CeO2-R, 2.605 g of Ce (NO3)3·6H2O and 28.8 g of NaOH were each dissolved separately in 15 mL and 105 mL of deionized water, respectively. After cooling, the Ce (NO3)3·6H2O solution was added dropwise to the NaOH solution, and the resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature to form a milky suspension. This suspension was transferred to a PTFE-lined autoclave where it was heated at 100 °C for a period of 24 h. After cooling, the solid product was extracted through centrifugation and rinsed with deionized water until neutralized, followed by ethanol washing. Finally, the sample was subjected to drying at 60 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to yield CeO2-R. For CeO2-C, the synthesis followed the same procedure as CeO2-R, with the reaction carried out at 180 °C for 24 h. The resulting catalyst support was labeled as CeO2-C. CeO2-S was synthesized by directly calcining Ce (NO3)3·6H2O at 350 °C for 4 h, yielding a pale yellow solid labeled as CeO2-S. 2.2.2 Preparation of Co/CeO2 catalysts For the preparation of Co/CeO2 catalysts, a suitable quantity of Co (NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in water and subsequently 3 g of CeO2 support was incorporated. The mixture was stirred for 8 h, dried overnight at a temperature of 110 °C, and calcined at 350 °C for 4 h, The calcined material was reduced under an H2 atmosphere (40 mL/min) at 450 °C for 6 h. Following cooling to room temperature in an H2 atmosphere, the sample was passivated overnight with a gas mixture (0.5 % O2/N2). The final Co/CeO2 catalysts, containing 20 wt% Co, were labeled as Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S, depending on the morphology of the CeO2 support. 2.3 Catalyst performance evaluation The performance of the catalysts in the ethylene glycol ammoxidation reaction was evaluated in a 50 mL high-pressure batch reactor. The following procedure was used: 1.5 g of ethylene glycol, 2.5‍ g of deionized water, 1.1 g of Co/CeO2 catalyst, and a glass stir bar were added to the reactor. The reactor was sealed and purged with N2 gas, and 5 g of liquid ammonia was added. The reactor was then pressurized with 3 MPa of H2, and a leak test was performed. After confirming there were no leaks, the reaction mixture was heated, and magnetic stirring was started. Once the reactor reached the desired reaction temperature, the reaction was timed for 12 h. Upon completion, the reactor was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, the remaining gas was released, and the reactor was subsequently opened. The overall mass of the reaction mixture was noted. High-speed centrifugation was employed to separate the reaction mixture from the catalyst, followed by the addition of an internal standard solution for quantitative analysis through gas chromatography. The reaction products were qualitatively analyzed employing a Shimadzu QP2010 Plus GC–MS system, utilizing helium as the carrier gas (1.0 mL/min flow rate, 30:1 split ratio). The temperatures for both the injector and detector were sustained at 250 °C. The separation was achieved using an Rtx-Wax capillary column, with a temperature program starting at 80 °C (held for 2 min), ramping to 110 °C at 15 °C/min, and then to 220 °C at 35 °C/min (held for 10 min). The FID temperature was 250 °C, with N2 as the carrier gas at 30 mL/min. For quantitative analysis, the internal standard approach was used, incorporating n-propanol as the internal standard in combination with anhydrous ethanol as the co-solvent. The ethylene glycol conversion for pure CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S were 13.26 %, 6.04 %, and 8.67 %, respectively, with no selectivity toward the target product, indicating that pure CeO2 exhibits poor ammoxidation activity. When Co was introduced, the glycol conversion and primary amine selectivity were significantly increased, confirming that Co serves as the primary active site in the amination reaction. However, the catalytic performance varied greatly among the Co/CeO2 catalysts. The ethylene glycol conversion for Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S were 93.66 %, 69.95 %, and 80.03 %, respectively, while the primary amine selectivities were 17.22 %, 33.79 %, and 23.43 %. These findings suggest that the ammoniation activity of Co/CeO2 catalysts can be effectively modified by adjusting the morphology of the CeO2 support. In order to test the stability of Co/CeO2 catalyst in the ethylene glycol reduction amination of ethylenediamine reaction (see Fig. 2 .). With the increase of the number of cycles, the conversion of EG decreased and the selectivity of the target product increased, which ensured that the total yield of the target product was maintained at more than 18 %, indicating that the Co/CeO2 -C has a good stability of the reaction. Niu Feng et al. found that the alcohol pretreatment catalyst could cause the carbon deposition on the surface of cobalt metal particles to block the sites of alcohol amination in the butanol amination reaction, thus significantly improving the selectivity of alcohol amination to primary amines[45]. The decrease in the conversion of EG with the increase in the number of cycles may be related to the carbon deposition on the surface of cobalt metal particles in the catalyst. From the above results, Co-CeO2-C combines the advantages of cheapness, high conversion, good reactivity, and green reaction conditions, which is very promising for the industrialization of ethylene glycol amination for the preparation of ethylenediamine. To further understand the influence of how CeO2 morphology affects the performance of Co/CeO2 catalysts, a comprehensive characterization was conducted, offering insights into the factors driving these performance variations. 3.2 Textural properties of the catalysts The morphology of the synthesized supports and catalysts was characterized by TEM (see Fig. 3 ). CeO2-R exhibits a rod-like rectangular prism shape, CeO2-C has a cubic structure, and CeO2-S is composed of layered fundamental units. After Co loading, the overall morphology of the catalysts remains almost unchanged with the original supports. However, in contrast to the pure supports, Co appears in the form of particles on the catalyst surfaces. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed to examine the crystal structure of CeO2 and Co/CeO2 catalysts (See Fig. 4 ). Diffraction peaks for CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S were observed at 2θ = 28.50°, 33.92°, 47.66°, 57.5°, 69.43°, 77.0°, and 79.3°, confirming that all the ceria crystals exhibit the fluorite cubic phases (PDF No. 34-0394, JCPDS 1984) [46]. The XRD patterns of Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S showed similar diffraction peaks, indicating that the crystal structure of CeO2 remained after Co loading. Additionally, a distinct diffraction peak at 2θ = 44.9°, corresponding to Co3O4 (PDF-ICDD 78–1970) [47], was observed, confirming that some of the loaded Co exist in the form of Co3O4. To further investigate the structure of the CeO2 and the state of Co in the Co/CeO2 catalysts, Raman spectroscopy was employed (See Fig. 5 ). The peak observed at 460 cm-1 in the Raman spectrum relates to the triply degenerate F2 g mode characteristic of the fluorite structure in CeO2. In contrast, the peak located at 595 cm-1 is linked to intrinsic oxygen vacancies that arise due to the presence of Ce3+ ‍[48,49]. Additionally, the peak at 680 cm-1 is attributed to Co3O4 [50]. Fig. 5(a) shows that all three CeO2 supports, regardless of morphology, exhibit a prominent peak at 460 cm-1, confirming the presence of the fluorite structure, consistent with the XRD results. The I595/I460 ratio in the Raman spectra was calculated to reflect the oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalysts. Integration of the 460 and 595 cm-1 peaks (see Table 2 ) showed that the oxygen vacancy ratios for CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S were 0.053, 0.025, and 0.039, respectively. After loading with Co, the fluorite structure characteristic peak at 460 cm-1 remained intact (See Fig. 5b). Notably, Co/CeO2-R exhibited the strongest peak at 595 cm-1, while Co/CeO2-C had the lowest. The integration of the 460 and 595 cm-1 peaks revealed I595/I460 ratios of 0.55, 0.19, and 0.21 for Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S, respectively, indicating that the oxygen vacancy concentration follows the order: Co/CeO2-R > Co/CeO2-S > Co/CeO2-C. Additionally, all Co/ CeO2 catalysts displayed a characteristic peak at 680 cm-1, suggesting that Co species are primarily present as Co3O4 particles, consistent with the XRD results. To explore more deeply the reduction characteristics of the CeO2 supports and of Co in the catalysts Co/CeO2, H2-TPR characterization was performed (See Fig. 6 ). As shown in Fig. 6(a), the H2 consumption peaks at 800–900 °C for CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S correspond to the reduction of bulk lattice oxygen in CeO2, while the reduction peaks between 400 and 600 °C are ascribed to the reduction of surface oxygen in CeO2 [51]. Lower reduction temperatures in the 400–600 °C range, along with larger H2 consumption peaks, indicate an increased presence of surface oxygen vacancies and an easier utilization of oxygen. The surface oxygen reduction peaks for CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S occurred at 526.7 °C, 612.3 °C, and 566.7 °C, respectively, indicating that the surface oxygen in CeO2-R is more easily reduced. The H2 consumption of CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S between 400 and 600 °C was calculated to be 180 μmol/g, 130 μmol/g, and 160 μmol/g, respectively. These results suggest that CeO2-R has the highest surface oxygen content, while CeO2-C has the lowest, consistent with the Raman spectroscopy. For the Co/CeO2 catalysts, significant reduction peaks were observed in the 200–400 °C range, indicating the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the associated valence shift from Co3+to Co2+ (see Fig. 6b). The H2 consumption values for Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S in this temperature range were 3310 μmol/g, 1790 μmol/g, and 2160 μmol/g, respectively (see Table 2). Considering the different concentrations of surface oxygen vacancies in CeO2-R, CeO2-C, and CeO2-S, it can be inferred that these vacancies interact strongly with cobalt, promoting the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+. To investigate the state of surface oxygen on Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S, the O 1s spectra were analyzed (see Fig. 7 a and Table 3 ). The spectra of three CeO2 supports revealed three distinct binding energies at 528.7–528.9 eV, s 530.4–530.7 eV, and 532.0 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (OL), surface-active oxygen species (OS), and adsorbed oxygen (OW), respectively [52–54]. By integrating the peak areas for each oxygen species, the ratio of OS/ (OL + OS + OW) was calculated for each of the Co/CeO2 catalysts (see Table 3). The ratio for Co/CeO2-R was 0.39, whereas Co/CeO2-C and Co/CeO2-S exhibited values of 0.24 and 0.25, respectively. These results indicated that Co/CeO2-R has the highest concentration of surface reactive oxygen species, while Co/CeO2-C is the lowest. This trend is consistent with the findings from the Raman spectroscopy and H2-TPR analyses [53,55]. The Ce 3d XPS spectra were also analyzed for the Co/CeO2 catalysts to further explore the electronic states of Ce (see Fig. 7b). The spectra consist of two sets of spin-orbit components, marked as u and v. The characteristic signals for Ce3+ are primarily observed at the v1 and u1 peaks, with binding energies of 885.3 eV and 903.4 eV, respectively, while the peaks at 882.5, 888.5, 897.9, 900.9, 907.0, and 916.4 eV, labeled as v0, v2, v3, and u0, u2, u3, correspond to Ce4+ [56]. By analyzing the Ce 3d spectra, the proportions of Ce3+ were calculated for the Co/CeO2 catalysts (see Table 3). The values for Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S were 22.5 %, 17.8 %, and 18.7 %, respectively. The Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio, commonly used to assess the relative concentration of oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 support [57], was found to be 0.29 for Co/CeO2-R, 0.21 for Co/CeO2-C, and 0.23 for Co/CeO2-S. These results indicate that Co/CeO2-R has the highest number of Ce3+ sites and thus the highest concentration of oxygen vacancies, which is correspond with the findings from the O 1s XPS and Raman analyses. Furthermore, the Co 2p XPS spectra of Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S catalysts were examined (see Fig. 7c). The binding energies of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks were observed to range from 793.0 to 797.5 eV and 777.0–782.5 eV, respectively, which are characteristic of Co2+ and Co3+ in the Co3O4 spinel phase [58,59]. Additionally, the measured separation between the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks, found to be between 15.1 and 15.3 eV, further confirms the presence of Co3O4 [60]. Therefore, Co3O4 is inferred to be the predominant Co species in these Co/CeO2 catalysts, which aligns with the XRD data. Fitting the Co 2p peaks reveals that the signals at binding energies of 781.5 eV and 796.5 eV are mainly attributed to Co2+, while those at 779.3 eV and 794.4 eV correspond to Co3+. Additionally, satellite peaks at 785.9 eV and 807.1 eV are characteristic of Co2+ [16,18]. The Co2+/Co3+ ratios followed the order: Co/CeO2-R > Co/CeO2-S > Co/CeO2-C, which is consistent with the order of the Ce3+/Ce4+ (see Table 4 ). This can be attributed to the higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio in the CeO2 support, which readily loses electrons, while the Co species gain electrons (Co3+ → Co2+) resulting in a higher Co2+/Co3+ ratio [41]. In summary, the number of oxygen vacancies and the chemical state of Co is closely related to the morphology of CeO2, and the higher concentrations of oxygen vacancies lead to a greater amount of Co2+ species. 4 Discussion 4.1 Factors influencing on EG conversion The above analysis shows that the amount of Co2+ species on Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S catalysts are different. Considering the activation and breaking CH bond of EG generally occur on the metal site, the existing state of Co might influence the absorption and activation of EG. Thus, EtOH-TPD experiments were conducted to study this effect (see Fig. 8 ). The mass spectrometry signal at M/Z = 45 corresponds to the ethanol desorption curve (see Fig. 8a). CeO2-R exhibited three prominent ethanol desorption peaks at 196 °C, 501 °C, and 689 °C, while CeO2-S shows a weak ethanol desorption peak at 250 °C, and CeO2-C displayed almost no ethanol desorption peaks. After Co loading, the Co/CeO2 catalysts all show a significant increase in ethanol adsorption (see Fig. 8b), indicating that the Co is the primary adsorption site for ethanol. As the morphology of CeO2 changes, the greatest amount was obtained on Co/CeO2-R. To quantifiably characterize the absorption capability of ethanol, the peak was integrated according to the peak areas (see Table 5 ). The result shows that the amount of absorbed ethanol on Co/CeO2-R and Co/CeO2-S are 3.23 and 1.85 times greater than Co/CeO2-C. Combined with the amount of Co2+ on the three catalysts, it can be deduced that the Co2+ is for EG absorption and activation. To verify the above deduction, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) was performed on Co/CeO2 catalysts with adsorbed ethylene glycol (EG) (see Fig. 10a). After adsorbing the similar amount of EG, spectra were recorded at a reaction temperature of 170 °C under Ar atmosphere. The characteristic CH stretching peaks at 2938 cm-1 and 2860 cm-1 and bending vibrational peaks at 1460 ‍cm-1 attributing to CH₂ were observed on all three catalysts, which indicates that the EG can absorption and activation on Co/CeO2 catalysts [61–63]. Though comparing the peak intensity at 2938 ‍cm-1 and 2860 cm-1, it can be found that the Co/CeO2-R shows the strongest intensity, and then the Co/CeO2-S, finally the Co/CeO2-C, in agreement with the EtOH-TPD results. These phenomena suggest that the Co2+ is beneficial for absorption and activation of EG, which might be helpful for EG conversion. The correlation between the catalyst's conversion rate and the content of Co2+ species also verifies this conclusion (see Fig. 9 ). The results show a direct relationship: a higher concentration of Co2+ species corresponds to a higher EG conversion. Conversely, a lower concentration of Co2+ leads to a reduced conversion rate. This suggests that Co2+ serves as the primary active site in the amination reaction, facilitating the cleavage of CH bonds in ethylene glycol to form amide intermediates, thereby driving the EG conversion. 4.2 Factors affecting the selectivity of ethylenediamine and ethanolamine As CeO2 supports can act as dual-function carriers, where oxygen vacancies create electron-deficient sites that interact with NH3, influencing its adsorption, dissociation, and subsequent reaction. As the oxygen vacancy concentration varies, the NH3 adsorption behavior of the catalysts can be significantly affected. To investigate this effect, the NH3/H2-TPD characterization were conducted on CeO2 supports and Co/CeO2 catalysts (see Fig. 11). The mass spectral signal at M/Z = 16 corresponds to NH3. As the H2 is easily reacts with surface oxygen on CeO2 to form H2O, the mass spectral signal at M/Z = 18 is used to track H2 desorption (see Fig. 11a). CeO2-R exhibits two strong NH3 desorption peaks at 146 °C and 345 °C, indicating the strongest NH3 adsorption capacity, consistent with its higher oxygen vacancy concentration. CeO2-C and CeO2-S display weaker NH3 desorption peaks, suggesting lower NH3 adsorption capacity. After Co loading, the NH3 and H2 desorption capacity occurs following a similar order as CeO2 supports:Co/CeO2-R > Co/CeO2-S > Co/CeO2-C (see Fig. 11b and c). This indicates that Co/CeO2-C exhibits the weakest H2 and NH3 adsorption. In reductive amination, it was reported that the stronger capability for absorption of ammonia and amine is a possible poison for the subsequent hydrogenation of the intermediate imine to methylamine [42]. Combined with the present result, it can be deduced that the weaker absorption of NH3 and H2 on Co/CeO2-C should be beneficial for primary amine intermediates and ethanolamine and ethylenediamine synthesis. To further verify the above deduction, the in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (In ‍situ ‍DRIFTS) was carried out on Co/CeO2 catalysts with adsorbed ethylene glycol (EG) (see Fig. 10 b). After adsorbing a similar amount of EG, spectra were recorded at a reaction temperature of 170 °C under NH3 and H2 atmosphere. The characteristic stretching peaks at 1659 cm-1 attributing to amide were observed on all three catalysts, indicating Co/CeO2 catalysts have the ability to form amide intermediates in enamine. Moreover, the peak areas at 1659 cm-1 over the three catalysts follow the below order: Co/CeO2-C > Co/CeO2-S > Co/CeO2-R (see Table 5). The selectivities of ethanolamine and ethylenediamine are correlated with the oxygen vacancy content, indicating an inverse relationship between the selectivities of ethanolamine and ethylenediamine and the oxygen vacancy content (see Fig. 11 d). These phenomenoa indicate that Co/CeO2-C catalysts with fewer oxygen vacancies is easily form amide intermediates after adsorbing a small amount of NH3, which is conducive to the formation of ethanolamine and ethylenediamine. In summary during the reductive amination of ethylene glycol, the morphology of CeO2 can regulate the electronic state of the metal Co through variations in the number of oxygen vacancies. Co/CeO2-R employing a larger amount of oxygen vacancies and Co2+ has a stronger ability to break CH bonds of EG, thereby promoting the conversion of ethylene glycol into amide intermediates. However, the larger number of acidic sites leads to excessive adsorption of ammonia and amine, which promotes the cyclization of intermediates and the formation of by-products such as piperazine, reducing ethanolamine and ethylenediamine selectivities. In contrast, the fewer oxygen vacancies on Co/CeO2-C catalyst have poor absorption for NH3, which can facilitate the easier formation of intermediate amide to generate primary amine by amide hydrogenation. Thus, higher yields of ethanolamine and ethylenediamine were obtained on the Co/CeO2-C catalyst (see Fig. 12 ). 5 Conclusions In conclusion, CeO2 supports with different morphologies contain varying numbers of oxygen vacancies, which can be used to regulate the Co2+/ Co3+ ratio, thereby enhancing the catalyst's ability to cleave CH bonds in alcohols and improving the conversion of ethylene glycol in reductive amination. Supports with fewer or moderate oxygen vacancies enable limited NH3 adsorption, which enhances the selectivity and yield of the target product. In the Co/CeO2 catalysts, Co species primarily exist in the form of Co3O4 clusters, interacting with the CeO2 support. For the Co/CeO2-R catalyst, the electron-rich environment around the oxygen vacancies stabilizes Co3+as Co2+, enhancing CH bond cleavage in ethylene glycol, resulting in a higher conversion rate. Conversely, the Co/CeO2-C catalyst, with fewer oxygen vacancies, allows for limited NH3 adsorption, reducing the formation of cyclic by-products and improving ethanolamine and ethylenediamine selectivity. This study provides new insights for understanding the effect of carrier properties and metal electronic states on EG amination reaction, which can supply guidelines for developing highly efficient catalysts for EG amination. coredata.dc:description: Co-based catalysts have demonstrated exceptional efficiency catalytic performance for ethylenediamine synthesis from ethylene glycol (EG) amination. However, the electronic effect of Co on the rate-determining step for breaking the CH bond of EG remains unclear, which is critical for EG amination. In the present study, three catalysts Co/CeO2-R, Co/CeO2-C, and Co/CeO2-S were synthesized, and the electronic state of Co species was modulated by changing CeO2 morphologies. Characterization results from TEM, XRD, Raman, H2-TPR, and XPS shown that CeO2 with a higher oxygen vacancy concentration helps stabilize Co2+, which is critical for breaking the CH bond and benefit for EG conversion. While, the lower oxygen vacancy concentration limits NH3 adsorption, which can depress the polymerization enamine intermediate and is benefit for ethylenediamine and ethanolamine synthesis. As a result, the Co/CeO2-R possessing the greatest amount of oxygen vacancy and Co2+ shows the highest EG conversion. While the Co/CeO2-C with fewer oxygen vacancies shows poor NH3 adsorption, depressing the formation of cyclic by-products and improving ethylenediamine and ethanolamine synthesis. A 23.63 % yield for ethylenediamine and ethanolamine was obtained on Co/CeO2-C catalyst. This study systematically examines the impact of CeO2 morphology on Co valence state and EG amination, which is helpful for designing highly effective catalysts for EG amination.
